PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is needed for conducting technical, 
economic, financial, governance, safeguards, gender and social due diligence for the ensuing 
project. It will apply recommendations from capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
7890 for mainstreaming climate resilience into preliminary designs, as well as inform and guide 
detailed engineering consultants recruited under the project design advance (PDA). The CDTA, 
PPTA, and PDA schedules are synchronized to maximize knowledge transfer.   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The key outputs are an agreed project design and feasibility study for the ensuing 
project that satisfies the requirements of ADB and the government. The PPTA will enhance 
project  readiness  by  assisting  the  government  in  undertaking  advance  actions,  including 
identification of lands for project facilities. The major outputs and activities are in Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA with an amount of $900,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). The  Government  will  provide  in-kind  support  in the form  of  office  accommodation, 
administrative support, supplies, field transport, and assign specialists as counterpart staff, and 
assistance in organizing workshops. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The TA will require about 82 person-months of consulting services (26 international and 
56  national).  Consulting  services  for  this  assignment  will  be  engaged  by  an  international 
consulting firm in association with national consulting firm(s) for a total of 67 person-months of 
consulting  services  (20  international  and  47  national).  ADB  will  recruit  an  additional  six 
consultants  on  an  individual  basis  for  a total  of  15  person months  (6  international  and  9 
national). A team of consultants will be recruited under one package using the quality- and cost-

based method of selection with a standard quality-cost ratio of 90:10.1 All consultants, including 
the firm and individuals, will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A simplified technical proposal will be used 
for the selection of a firm. The individual consultants will be engaged to undertake safeguards 
due diligence, provide technical inputs, and enhance project readiness (Table A4.3).

5.  The outline terms of reference for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
below.  During a period of 8 months, the PPTA will formulate the design of the project to be 
mutually agreed upon between the government and ADB. The TA will adequately address the 
following aspects relating to the ensuing loan project: (i) the rationale for selecting project towns 
and  confirmation  of  priority  subprojects  in  each  municipality;  (ii)  assessment  of  technical, 
procurement, and management capacity of the executing agency, project towns and other key 
agencies involved in the project; (iii) financial assessment of the project towns, including their 
financial  projections,  and  proposals  for  sustainable  operation  and  maintenance  of  project 
facilities; (iv) formulation of appropriate financial and institutional arrangements; (v) preparation 
of feasibility study of selected projects, including preliminary engineering designs and financial 
and economic analyses, which incorporates considerations of climate change adaptation;2 (vi)

    the most technically qualified team of specialists to ensure effective demonstration in the ensuing project and

social, gender, and poverty analysis; (vii) preparation of a consultation and participation plan; 
(viii) preparation of required safeguard documents; (ix) assessment of governance risks in the 
areas of financial management, procurement, and corruption, and development of risk mitigation 
measures based on the assessment for minimizing procurement and financial management 
risks; (x) assess and review status of any town plans (land use, drainage, etc.) and investment 
proposals in light of better medium- to long-term urban planning and enforcement of necessary 
land use and building regulations and bylaws, and development of recommendations to improve 
these plans incorporating climate change considerations; (xi) proposed loan procurement plan 
for goods, works, and services, with suggested level of prior or, if applicable, post review based 
on  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  capacity  assessment;  (xii)  assistance  in 
preparation  of  government  development  project  proforma  (DPP);  and  (xii)  proposal  of 
implementation  schedule,  detailed  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan,  as  well  as  required 
consultant inputs under the project with proposed sequencing of consultant recruitment and 
procurement bidding and awarding. 
 
6.  Consultants will also provide support to enhance project readiness and expedite project 
start-up by: (i) undertaking training of relevant officials involved in the project, (ii) assisting the 
executing agency and project municipalities in undertaking advance contracting, mainly for 
recruitment of consultants for the project, and in (iii) undertaking other necessary actions such 
as land acquisition in accordance with the agreed resettlement plans. Consultants will prepare 
necessary documents required for project processing and implementation acceptable to ADB.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
7.  The  executing  agency  is  LGED  of  the  Ministry  of  Local  Government,  Rural 
Development  and  Cooperatives.  A  steering  committee,  chaired  by  the  Secretary,  Local 
Government Division, will provide overall policy guidance for the PPTA.3 The government will 
provide: (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, information, and maps that are available at 
the disposal of the government; (ii) qualified counterpart staff, including their field per diem and 
field transportation; (iii) a TA director from LGED, to be assigned before the mobilization of the 
consultants; (iv) office accommodation and office equipment, including desks, chairs, and local 
communication; and (v) logistical assistance for the workshops and seminars, including venue 
provision and identifying and sending invites to participants. The equipment procured under the 
TA will be turned over to LGED at the end of the TA. A suitably staffed project management unit 
(PMU) will be established by LGED at its headquarters in Dhaka.  All disbursements under the 
TA shall be made in accordance with the TA Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended 
from time to time). The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table 
A4.4. The estimated start and completion dates of the TA are August 2012 to August 2013.  
 
   
                                                
3 Steering Committee membership will include LGED, Department of Public Health Engineering, Ministry of 
Environment and Forests (Climate Change Unit), representatives of project towns, Urban Development Directorate, 
Disaster Management Bureau, Bangladesh Water Development Board, Economic Relations Division and Finance 
Division of the Ministry of Finance, and Planning Commission.
